p: Huge dilemma exists in the treatment of CVST with BD. The European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) agreed that high dose glucocorticoids should be used for acute CVST. No data shows the benefit of adding immunosuppressants in the acute CVST, and immunosuppressants may also be unnecessary for the relapses of the CVST with BD. Anticoagulants may be added, but only for a short time ( 2). It is reported recently that a patient with CVST related to BD came with headaches and vision changes that was resolved after 5 sessions of plasmapheresis along with steroids and anticoagulation, which provides another alternative option of treatment ( 3). In acute deep venous thrombosis other than CVST, glucocorticoids and immunosuppressants such as cyclophosphamide are recommended, and anticoagulants may be added provided that coexistent pulmonary artery aneurysms are ruled out ( 2).
